facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 218 to 221 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 218 to 221 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and orders dated May 21, 1964 of Madhya Pradesh High Court Indore Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders, dated May 21, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Indore Bench  at Indore

facts.text: High Court decided Criminal Appeals Nos. 30 and 31 of 1962, Nos. 246 and 258 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeals Nos. 30 and 31 of 1962 Nos. 246 and 258 of 1963 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant convicted in four cases of offence under section 409 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, in these four appeals by special leave, was companyvicted in four cases of an offence under s. 409 I.P.C.

facts.text: In first two cases, appellant sentenced to 4 years rigorous imprisonment and fine on January 17, 1962 by First Additional Sessions Judge Ujjain, Shri B. Aggarwal.

anchor.surface_text: and was sentenced to 4 years rigorous imprisonment and fine in the first two cases on January 17, 1962, by the First Additional Sessions Judge, Ujjain, Shri B. Aggarwal.

facts.text: Appellant also convicted in first two cases under s.467 read with s.471 and s.477A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He was also companyvicted in these two cases of offences under s. 467 read with s. 471 and s. 477A I.P.C.

facts.text: Sentences for other offences in first two cases run concurrently with sentence under s.409 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences imposed for these offences were to run companycurrently with the sentence of imprisonment for the of- fence under s. 409 I.P.C.

facts.text: Sentences under s.409 in first two cases to run consecutively.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences imposed in the two cases for the offence under s. 409 I.P.C. were to run companysecutively as numberorder had been made by the Sessions Judge for the sentence in the case in which judgment was pronounced later, to run companycurrently with the sentence imposed in the other case.

facts.text: In other two cases, appellant sentenced to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under s.409 IPC on July 20, 1963 by Shri Dube, First Additional Sessions Judge Ujjain.

anchor.surface_text: In each of the other two cases, the appellant was sentenced to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under S. 409 I.P.C. by Shri Dube, First Additional Sessions Judge, Ujjain, on July 20, 1963.

facts.text: Sentences in other two cases ordered to run concurrently with each other but not with first case.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge ordered the sentences in these two cases to run companycurrently, but did number order them to run companycurrently with the sentence awarded in the first case on January 17, 1962.

facts.text: Appeals against convictions in four cases dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals against the companyviction of the appellant in the four cases were dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: High Court considered 4 years RI under s.409 in first case not excessive, somewhat lenient, fine feeble.

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the sentence in the appeal against the first companyviction in Sessions Trial No. 35 of 1961, the High Court said Coming to the sentences, the basic offence is criminal breach of trust under section 409 IPC and a sentence of four years rigorous imprisonment cannot, in these circumstances, be companysidered excessive. If anything, I would call it somewhat lenient. The sentence of fine of Rs. 1,000 was companysidered to be feeble.

facts.text: High Court noted sentence in second case low considering other cases.

anchor.surface_text: In disposing of the appeal against the companyviction in the second case, Sessions Trial No. 36 of 1961, the High Court said with respect of the sentence The sentence of imprisonment is also low but possibly the Sessions Court took account of the fact that there were other and similar cases against Ranchhodlal in which there was a possibility of a companyviction.

facts.text: Appellant named Ranchhodlal.

anchor.surface_text: other and similar cases against Ranchhodlal

facts.text: High Court would have increased sentence in third case if applied for.

anchor.surface_text: In the third appeal from the order in Sessions Trial No. 55 of 1962, the High Court said If there had been an application for enhancement of sentence, I would number have hesitated to increase the sentence because this paying himself on the part of the appellant is a very serious matter.

facts.text: High Court found 3 years sentence in fourth case lenient.

anchor.surface_text: In the fourth appeal, the High Court said The trial Court has awarded a sentence of three years without fine. It is quite lenient.

facts.text: Result of convictions: appellant to undergo 11 years imprisonment mainly for offences under s.409 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the four companyvictions and sentences passed in these cases is that the appellant has to undergo imprisonment for 11 years for mainly companymitting the offences under s. 409 I.P.C.

facts.text: Offences with respect to different amounts in capacity as Sarpanch of Mandal Panchayat, Ujjain.

anchor.surface_text: with respect to different amounts, in his capacity as Sarpanch of the Mandal Panchayat, Ujjain.

issues.text: Whether the sentencing courts erred by not directing the subsequent sentences to run concurrently with the previous sentences under s. 397 Cr. P.C.?

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  1  of s. 397, Cr. P.C. provides that when a person already undergoing a sentence of imprisonment is sentenced on a subsequent conviction to imprisonment, such imprisonment shall commence at the expiration of the imprisonment to which he has been previously sentenced, unless the Court directs that the subsequent sentence shall run concurrently with such previous sentence.

issues.text: Whether the various acts of criminal breach of trust should have been charged as a single offence specifying the gross sum under s. 222 Cr. P.C.?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has not urged that there is any illegality in the sentences awarded to the appellant in the various Sessions cases or in not making them run concurrently with the sentence awarded in the first Sessions Trial No. 35 of 1961. He has, however, urged that the various acts of criminal breach of trust which formed the basis of the convictions took place within a period of a few months, from November 19, 1955 to February 23, 1956, and that therefore the appellant should have been charged for committing criminal breach of trust with respect to the total amount he had misappropriated, in view of s. 222 Cr. C.

issues.text: Whether the offences of criminal breach of trust could and should have been jointly tried under s. 234 Cr. P.C. as offences of the same kind committed within twelve months?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant also relied on s. 234 Cr. C. and urged that three offences of criminal breach of trust could have been tried at one trial as s. 234 provides that when a person is accused of more offences than one of the same kind committed within the space of twelve months from the first to the last of such offences,

issues.text: Whether all the offences of criminal breach of trust were committed in the course of the same transaction and should have been tried at one trial under s. 235 Cr. P.C.?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, reference was made, on behalf of the appellant, to s. 235 Cr. P.C. and it was urged that all these offences were committed in the course of the same transaction, and therefore, they should have been tried at one trial. Assuming, without deciding, that these offences could be said to have been committed in the course of the same transaction,

issues.text: Whether the total sentence of 11 years rigorous imprisonment for offences under s. 409 I.P.C. is excessive and warrants interference?

arguments.claim: Being tried in four separate cases for criminal breach of trust with respect to different amounts led to prejudice and harassment due to consecutive sentences of imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: One of the grounds taken in the special leave petitions was that his being tried in four cases for committing criminal breach of trust with respect to different amounts, led to the petitioners prejudice and harassment inasmuch as he was to undergo sentences, of imprisonment consecutively.

arguments.court_reasoning: Separate trials not illegal; no evidence of design in prosecution; investigating agency submitted chargesheets sequentially.

arguments.claim: Subsequent sentences of imprisonment ordinarily commence after expiration of previous sentence unless court directs concurrency under s.397(1) CrPC, and courts erred by not directing concurrency.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 1 of s. 397, Cr. P.C. provides that when a person already undergoing a sentence of imprisonment is sentenced on a subsequent conviction to imprisonment, such imprisonment shall commence at the expiration of the imprisonment to which he has been previously sentenced, unless the Court directs that the subsequent sentence shall run concurrently with such previous sentence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not urged before Sessions Judges or High Court; sentencing courts exercised discretion properly; High Court viewed sentences as lenient.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has not urged that there is any illegality in the sentences awarded to the appellant in the various Sessions cases or in not making them run concurrently with the sentence awarded in the first Sessions Trial No. 35 of 1961. He has, however, urged that the various acts of criminal breach of trust which formed the basis of the convictions took place within a period of a few months, from November 19, 1955 to February 23, 1956, and that therefore the appellant should have been charged for committing criminal breach of trust with respect to the total amount he had misappropriated, in view of s. 222 Cr. C.

arguments.claim: Total sentence of 11 years RI for offences under s.409 IPC is severe/excessive; if tried at one trial under s.222, sentence would not exceed 4 years (normal maximum).
arguments.court_reasoning: s.409 punishable up to life/10 years; sentence governed by nature/circumstances; deterrent needed for public servant misappropriating public funds.

arguments.claim: No illegality in not directing sentences in all four cases to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: It was not urged before the High Court that the sentences in all the four cases be made to run concurrently.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ions Judge who companyvicted the appellant in two cases in January 1962 did number exercise his discretion in favour of the appellant. The other Sessi

arguments.court_reasoning: Petitioner conceded no illegality in sentences or lack of concurrency.

arguments.claim: s.397 CrPC confers discretion on sentencing court to order subsequent sentence concurrent or consecutive; exercised properly here.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 1 of s. 397, Cr. P.C. provides that when a person already undergoing a sentence of imprisonment is sentenced on a subsequent conviction to imprisonment, such imprisonment shall commence at the expiration of the imprisonment to which he has been previously sentenced, unless the Court directs that the subsequent sentence shall run concurrently with such previous sentence. It follows that a subsequent sentence of imprisonment is ordinarily to commence at the expiration of imprisonment under the previous sentence, and that the Court recording the conviction has the discretion to order that the later sentence would run concurrently with the previous one.

arguments.claim: s.222(2) CrPC is exception to normal rule of separate charges under s.233 for each distinct offence; not applicable here.

anchor.surface_text: Section 222 Cr. P.C. reads The charge shall contain such particulars as to the time and place of the alleged offence... When the accused is charged with criminal breach of trust or dishonest misappropriation of money, it shall be sufficient to specify the gross sum... Sub-section 2 is an exception to meet a certain contingency and is not the normal rule with respect to framing of a charge in cases of criminal breach of trust. The normal rule is that there should be a charge for each distinct offence, as provided in s. 233 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Separate trials for distinct offences of criminal breach of trust is correct mode; no illegality in four separate trials.

anchor.surface_text: If several distinct item with respect to which criminal breach of trust has been committed are not so lumped together, no illegality is committed in the trial of those offences. In fact, a separate trial with respect to each distinct offence of criminal breach of trust with respect to an individual item is the correct mode of proceeding with the trial of an offence of criminal breach of trust.

arguments.claim: ss.234 and 235 CrPC are enabling provisions; separate trials not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: This again, is an enabling provision and is an exception to s. 233 Cr. P.C. If each of the several offences is tried separately, there is nothing illegal about it... This section too is an enabling section. Apart from the fact that the separate trials of the appellant in four cases for committing breach of trust with respect to several items was not illegal,

arguments.claim: No evidence investigating agency knew all offences before first trial; sequential prosecutions not designed to prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that the separate trials of the appellant in four cases for committing breach of trust with respect to several items was not illegal, there is nothing on record to show that the investigating agency had worked out all the cases of criminal breach of trust prior to prosecuting the appellant for the offences of which he was tried at Sessions Trial No. 35 of 1961... The fact that the first two Sessions Trials ended in a conviction in January 1962 on commitments made sometime in 1961 and that the Sessions Trials ending on July 20, 1963 were on commitments made sometime in 1962, prima facie indicate that the investigating agency submitted the charge sheets against the appellant for the offences tried in 1963 after-and possibly long after it had submitted charge-sheet with respect to the first two cases. There cannot therefore be any design in prosecuting the appellant for different offences in four cases.

arguments.claim: Sentence under s.409 IPC not limited to 4 years; up to life/10 years; discretion to adjust per circumstances; deterrent justified.

holdings.text: There had been no illegality in the Courts trying the appellant in four cases and in not ordering the various sentences awarded in different Sessions Trials to run concurrently with the sentences awarded in Session Trial No. 35 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that there had been no illegality in the Courts trying the appellant in four cases and in not ordering the various sentences awarded in different Sessions Trials to run concurrently with the sentences awarded in Session Trial No. 35 of 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate trials permissible under CrPC; no evidence of prosecutorial design; sentencing courts exercised discretion properly; not urged before lower courts.

holdings.text: A subsequent sentence of imprisonment is ordinarily to commence at the expiration of imprisonment under the previous sentence, unless the Court directs concurrency under s.397(1) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that a subsequent sentence of imprisonment is ordinarily to commence at the expiration of imprisonment under the previous sentence, and that the Court recording the conviction has the discretion to order that the later sentence would run concurrently with the previous one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.397(1) CrPC; discretion lies with sentencing court.

holdings.text: Sub-section (2) of s.222 CrPC is an exception to the normal rule of separate charges for each distinct offence under s.233 CrPC; lumping into gross sum only in specific contingencies where exact items or dates impossible.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 is an exception to meet a certain contingency and is not the normal rule with respect to framing of a charge in cases of criminal breach of trust. The normal rule is that there should be a charge for each distinct offence, as provided in s. 233 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of ss.222, 233 CrPC; exception not mandatory.

holdings.text: If several distinct items of criminal breach of trust are not lumped together under s.222(2), no illegality in trial; separate trial for each distinct offence is the correct mode.

anchor.surface_text: If several distinct item with respect to which criminal breach of trust has been committed are not so lumped together, no illegality is committed in the trial of those offences. In fact, a separate trial with respect to each distinct offence of criminal breach of trust with respect to an individual item is the correct mode of proceeding with the trial of an offence of criminal breach of trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Normal procedure under CrPC requires specificity per distinct offence.

holdings.text: s.234 CrPC is an enabling provision permitting joint trial of up to three similar offences within 12 months; separate trials of each offence not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: This again, is an enabling provision and is an exception to s. 233 Cr. P.C. If each of the several offences is tried separately, there is nothing illegal about it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enabling exception to s.233; exceeded limit anyway.

holdings.text: Even assuming offences committed in course of same transaction, s.235 CrPC enabling; separate trials not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, without deciding, that these offences could be said to have been committed in the course of the same transaction, the separate trial of the appellant for certain specific offences is not illegal. This section too is an enabling section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enabling provision; no mandate for joinder.

holdings.text: No evidence that investigating agency knew of all offences before first trial; sequential charge sheets indicate no design to prejudice appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that the separate trials of the appellant in four cases for committing breach of trust with respect to several items was not illegal, there is nothing on record to show that the investigating agency had worked out all the cases of criminal breach of trust prior to prosecuting the appellant for the offences of which he was tried at Sessions Trial No. 35 of 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prima facie inference from dates of commitments and trials.

holdings.text: Total sentence of 11 years RI under s.409 IPC not excessive; punishable up to life or 10 years; discretion to adjust per circumstances; deterrent sentence justified for public servant misappropriating public funds.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory range allows; public interest demands deterrence given position of trust.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that there had been numberillegality in the Courts trying the appellant in four cases and in number ordering the various sentences awarded in different Sessions Trials to run companycurrently with

outcome.relief_summary: No illegality in separate trials or in directing consecutive sentences; no reduction in sentence; convictions and sentences upheld
